key_points: Hurricane Ida has become one of New Jersey's deadliest storms, with a death toll rising to 25.
Gov. Phil Murphy announced the death toll and stated that six people were still missing.
Most fatalities occurred after victims were trapped in vehicles overtaken by floodwaters, particularly in Central New Jersey.
Ida is considered the deadliest storm in New Jersey since Hurricane Sandy in 2012, which had a death toll of 34 according to the CDC.
The storm has caused nationwide fatalities with at least 45 people dead, concentrated in New Jersey and New York.
Intense rain and tornadoes contributed to the devastation brought by Ida, surpassing the impact of previous storms like Sandy and Irene.
Gov. Murphy and other Democrats attribute the increasing frequency and intensity of storms to climate change.
New Jersey's geographic location and dense population make it particularly vulnerable to such natural disasters.
Gov. Murphy underscored the necessity of enhancing the country's infrastructure to mitigate damage from future storms.
The White House approved New Jersey's disaster declaration, enabling FEMA to assist with the emergency response.
spokespersons: Gov. Phil Murphy (Governor of New Jersey)
